content.webTitle: OK, we’ve had our fun. Now wash the trunks away | Barbara Ellen

fields.headline: OK, we’ve had our fun. Now wash the trunks away
fields.bodyText: I don’t know much about art, but I like Antony Gormley’s “Iron Men” statues (official name: Another Place) on the sands at Crosby, Merseyside. There’s a sombre dignity, a sense of permanence, about them, and it’s great that the public is able to interact with them. Except perhaps when the public interacts too much. Someone has been “vandalising” them – by which I mean they’ve painted a polka-dot bikini on one (a tad jarring when teamed with the pronounced male anatomical details? I’ll let you decide) and shorts, shirts and the words “I am art” on others. This isn’t the first time that the Iron Men have been “embellished”– by whom remains an enduring mystery, though previously Everton and Liverpool football shirts were involved. Gormley has now politely requested that the statues be cleaned and left alone, which is fair enough. Doodling beach-grundies on to his artwork is no way to thank Gormley for allowing the statues to stay on at Crosby when they were originally intended to move to New York. Let this be the end of the matter, though it must be said that, in the hot and difficult week just passed, at least one philistine was grateful for the chuckle.
